justification: In Study 1, the hidden-zero effect was measured using a paper-based questionnaire comprising hypothetical risky choice pairs and analyzed with hierarchical Bayesian modeling to assess choice preference and attentional bias toward certain options.

measured_by: Selection Bias (SB) scores derived from eye-movement data
justification: Attentional bias was quantified through SB scores (SBoption, SBzero_outcome, SBnon-zero_outcome) derived from eye-movement recordings, incorporated as empirical attentional bias in the cognitive models to predict choice preference.
Participants completed the Risk Propensity Scale to measure their general risk-taking attitude, which was controlled for in the analysis to examine its effect on decision-making under risky choices.
Choice preference was analyzed using Hierarchical Bayesian Analysis, comparing different attentional risk aversion (aRA) models to evaluate the impact of attentional biases on choices.

measured_by: Attentional Bias (AB) scores from fixation data
justification: The attention allocation pattern was measured using attentional bias scores calculated from the dwell time within regions of interest for the certain and risky options, as well as their respective outcomes.
